heading: blue chips back in form
subheading: tech and net stocks are elbowed aside as investors renew their affection for wall street's old guard. like clockwork, traders are once again leery of sky-high prices. by david lazarus.
author: david lazarus
text: in a tit-for-tat reversal, blue chip stocks were snatching back the market's leadership position tuesday, and tech and internet shares were struggling to catch up as investors chewed over some of those blubbery valuations. the dow jones industrial average rose 85.91 points to 10804.50 in mid-afternoon trading, fueled in large part by some solid earnings from at&t and news that international business machines plans to buy back a bunch of its shares. the blue-chip index was off its earlier highs, but still showing vitality.can't say the same for the silicon and dot-com crowd. investors wasted little time in distancing themselves from many of the stocks that had been out front in recent sessions as worries crept back in about towering price-earnings ratios. some selling in the morning quickly turned into a wholesale retreat as traders chose to play it safe by pocketing their winnings.the wired index slid 5.57 to 677.15, and the nasdaq composite index was 39.82 lower at 2612.23. the s&p 500 was up 0.91 at 1360.95.joseph battipaglia, chief investment officer at gruntal & co., said net stocks in particular are running into "very sizable resistance." one factor, he added, is that everyone who wanted to attend this particular party already may be in the house."who's left that hasn't bought internet stocks that wanted to?" battipaglia wondered. "people are saying these are very wonderful companies, but enough already, price-wise."tell that to the day traders. while net stocks may be running short of long-term investors, there are still plenty of itchy-fingered cowboys gathered in darkened rooms who remain more than willing to throw money -- for a minute or two -- at anything with an online pedigree.the latest beneficiary of this lunacy is an outfit called razorfish (razf), a new york web-design firm. its stock more than doubled to us$32.75 on its first trading day after debuting with 3 million shares initially priced at $16 apiece. at least razorfish comes with some impressive credentials, including clients like ebay and charles schwab. once the day traders have their say, and the company's stock settles at a more sensible level, this might be one to take a closer look at.speaking of ebay (ebay), everyone's favorite beanie baby emporium declined $1.50 to $207.50 after beating estimates with quarterly income of 5 cents a share. apparently, not many people were paying attention when he company's stock was upgraded by salomon smith barney to "buy" from "outperform."meanwhile, amazon.com (amzn) slipped $2.44 to $204.75 on word that it had shelled out $645 million for a trio of new acquisitions aimed at boosting its online offerings. among the purchases is exchange.com, a purveyor of rare books and music. amazon is expected to report a widening loss when it posts its latest results on wednesday.of perhaps greater interest will be america online's (aol) showing when it reveals its own earnings after the closing bell. profit of 9 cents a share is anticipated -- and aol said last week that it's "comfortable" with this number -- but investors are eager to see if the company can do even better, and whether quarterly revenue will surpass a billion dollars for the first time ever.with expectations running so high, many on the street are bracing for disappointment. aol's shares were down $4.94 at $157.06.
